docs.snippet: The following is Lieut.-Commanding PHILLIPS' report to Flag-Officer FOOTE, received to-day at the Headquarters of the Army, by telegraph from Cairo:

headline.main: OPERATIONS IN TENNESSEE; Flag-Officer Foote's Report of the Battle of Fort Henry. The Advance of the National Gunboats into Alabama.Six Rebel Steamers Burnedand Three Captured.QUANTITIES OF MILITARY STORES SEIZED The National Forces EverywhereReceived with Joy.Enthusiastic Exhibition of Loyalty to the Government.THE ERPEDITION UP THE TENNESSEE OFFICIAL REPORT TO FLAG-OFFICER FOOTE, ETC. REPORTS FROM CINCINNATI. REPORTS FROM ST. LOUIS. THE REPORT OF FLAG-OFFICER FOOTE. THANKS TO COMMODORE FOOTE. MOVEMENTS OF NATIONAL TROOPS. GEN. HITCHCOCK A MAJOR-GENERAL. FROM PORT ROYAL.

docs.lead_paragraph: The following is Lieut.-Commanding PHILLIPS' report to Flag-Officer FOOTE, received to-day at the Headquarters of the Army, by telegraph from Cairo:

docs.snippet: From officers arrived this morning from Mill Springs, I learn that news has been brought to that point by Union people living on the road through Monticello and Albany, to Tennessee, of the prevalence of an intense panic among the secession...
docs.lead_paragraph: From officers arrived this morning from Mill Springs, I learn that news has been brought to that point by Union people living on the road through Monticello and Albany, to Tennessee, of the prevalence of an intense panic among the secession sympathizers on both sides of the State line. Hundreds of families have turned off toward the interior of Tennessee, since the running passage of the remnants...

docs.snippet: In a former letter I told you that the rebel authorities, disgusted with the inefficiency of those in command at their batteries, had put them under arrest, and it now appears that they have superseded.

headline.main: REMOVAL OF THE REBEL FORCES TO KENTUCKY; BETTER FIRING WALKER'S BATTERY GONE AFFAIRS ON THE FLOTILLA OUR TROOPS QUIET, WITH LITTLE PROSPECT OF A MOVE, ETC.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a former letter I told you that the rebel authorities, disgusted with the inefficiency of those in command at their batteries, had put them under arrest, and it now appears that they have superseded.

docs.snippet: Advices from Ship Island, brought by the ship Bullion, are to Jan. 20. All was quiet there, and the health of the troops good. Only one death had occurred.

headline.main: FROM SHIP ISLAND.; The Command in Good Health Loss of One Hundred and Forty-five Horses.

docs.lead_paragraph: Advices from Ship Island, brought by the ship Bullion, are to Jan. 20. All was quiet there, and the health of the troops good. Only one death had occurred.

headline.main: NEWS FROM REBELDOM.; A Rebel View of the Condition of Affairs in Eastern Tennessee. Excitement at Nashville Following the Battle at Mill Spring. A SERMON ON THE USES OF ADVERSITY. Straws Showing which Way the Rebel Wind Blows. Condition of Society at the Rebel Capital. INTERESTING MISCELLANEOUS NEWS. STATE OF AFFAIRS IN EASTERN TENNESSEE.

headline.main: THE BROOKLYN SKATING CARNIVAL.; 5,000 PERSONS ON THE ICE. Characters in Costume, Music, Fireworks, and General Jubilee.

docs.lead_paragraph: Winter has its own delight many, indeed, which, in the estimation of the wholesome Northern temperament, Summer, with all her splendors, cannot rival. docs.snippet: A flag of truce from Craney Island, to-day, brought over several ladies, to go North.

headline.main: THE BURNSIDE EXPEDITION; The Attack upon Roanoke Island Commenced. REPORTS RECEIVED FROM THE REBELS. The National Forces Said to Have Been Twice Repulsed.
